dict.string: IRC stands for Internet Relay Chat and was created in 1988. IRC is a way for people to talk to each other online. It allows for group conferencing with many users, as well as private messaging between two users. There are over a thousand IRC networks to chat on, with hundreds of thousands of channels covering thousands of chat topics.
With Colloquy, a Direct IRC Connection is a connection between your mobile device and the chat server that you are connected to. The alternative to a direct IRC connection is to use a bouncer.

In IRC terms, a bouncer is a piece of software that sits between you and the IRC server that you are connected to. This allows you to do a number of things, including connecting to the same room from multiple locations and stay connected to IRC when Colloquy has been closed.

Due to the usefulness IRC bouncers, we have created a plugin for Desktop Colloquy that turns it into a bouncer. In addition to being a normal bouncer, the Colloquy bouncer also generates Push Notifications that are sent to your device and syncs connections over from your desktop running Colloquy to the mobile version of Colloquy on your iPhone or iPod touch.

There are two parts to setting up Colloquy's bouncer; setting Desktop Colloquy up and setting Mobile Colloquy up:

Part one: On the Desktop, the first thing you'll need to do is to the latest version of Colloquy. This will have the bouncer plugin built. After that, open Colloquy's preferences and go over to the Bouncer tab. Fill out the appropriate fields as necessary and write the values down if you need to. Although Colloquy will attempt to forward ports automatically with your router, however this may not work. You can check to make sure the port is forwarded at http://www.canyouseeme.org/. If the port is not forwarded, you can consult http://portforward.com for details on how to forward ports in your router.

Part two: On Mobile Colloquy, go to the Connections tab and hit the + button in the top left corner and select "Colloquy Bouncer" from the menu. Fill out the fields as necessary. The "Address" should have the IP address of the computer running Desktop Colloquy. You can find this out by visiting http://colloquy.info/ip.php on your desktop. Hit "Connect" in the top left corner once the fields are filled out, and if all went well, your iPhone or iPod touch will connect to your desktop and set everything else up for you.

Notes: If you could not connect the two devices, it means there is something interfering with the communication. Check to make sure your firewall isn't blocking incoming or outgoing traffic from Colloquy and that the port is open.

There are over a thousand networks and hundreds of thousands of chat rooms on IRC. Colloquy conveniently provides a list of around 25 of networks that you can join and chat. You can find this list by hitting the + button on the Connections tab, creating an IRC Connection and hitting the blue button in the Address field.

Once you picked a network to talk on (All the networks great, if you can't decide, pick one at random. You can always go back and create another connection!), you need to find a chat room to talk on. Colloquy also provides a built in way of doing this. Under the Colloquies tab, hit the + button and selecting "Join a Chat Room". Then hit the blue button in the Name field. If you have a specific topic you want to discuss, you can search for it. Otherwise, scroll down until you find a room to chat in, and have fun!

If you would like to search for additional network to chat on, you can find a list at http://netsplit.de/ and additional chat rooms can be found by searching on http://searchirc.com/. When in a chat room, you can also "/search word (or phrase)" and it will automatically open up searchirc.com with a search for your word or phrase.

Push Notifications are a big part of the iPhone OS now. Colloquy is the first IRC client on the iPhone that supports Push Notifications! Due to how IRC works, Colloquy is a bit untraditional in how it has to generate Push Notifications. Instead of us running a server on our own, you have to run a bouncer that will create Push Notifications. To date, there are three ways of creating creating Push Notifications:

  1. Using the Colloquy bouncer, as detailed in the "Colloquy Bouncer" section. This method will only work on Mac OS X Leopard or above.
  2. Using ZNC (http://znc.in) with the Colloquy Push plugin. This will work on Mac OS X, Linux and Windows.
  3. Using a script for Irssi, that can be found at: (insert link for irssi plugin). This should also work on Mac OS X, Linux and Windows.

Scripts and plugins for additional clients are planned - or may already exist - but are not ready when Colloquy was submitted to the App Store. You can check for more scripts at http://colloquy.info/project/wiki/PushNotifications.

Colloquy has a very large number of settings that you can use to customize how you interact with the application. Settings for Colloquy can be found in Settings.app, under Colloquy. Some examples of settings that Colloquy has are Styles to change how chat looks, different sounds on different kinds of alerts and the option to disable history on reconnect.

If you already know what server you want to go to, Colloquy makes it very easy to connect! Just tap the + button on the Connections tab, select "IRC Connection" and enter the server address. You can tell Colloquy to always automatically join rooms by adding them to the Join Rooms list or to automatically connect to the network when Colloquy is opened. Under Advanced, you can do things like change the server port, toggle SSL status, and enter a password for your nickname or for the server as necessary.

There are a number of ways to join chat rooms in Colloquy! The first way is to add the room to the "Join Rooms" list when creating the connection. The second way to join a chat room is to tap the + button in the Colloquies tab, select "Join a Chat Room", to enter the room name and hit Join. If the room has a channel password, you can enter it here. You can also type "/join #room" or tap on a room name in chat to join the room.

A complete list of commands that Colloquy supports is:
  • /amazon item - This will search for Amazon. Locations are limited to Great Britain, Germany, China, Japan, France, Canada and United States.
  • /browser [last] [site] - Without any arguments, this will open up Colloquy's built in web browser. Typing "/browser last" will open the last website that you visited in Colloquy's browser. "/browser http://colloquy.mobi" will open up the browser to the website specified, in this case, Mobile Colloquy's website.
  • /clear - This will remove all chat on screen.
  • /faq - See /help.
  • /google [locale] search - Opens up a search with Google for your search terms. It will default to searching in whatever language your device is set to, however you can specify a custom language if you like.
  • /help - This will bring up the welcome screen so you can reference the built in help guides and watch the screencasts again as necessary.
  • /ipod - See /music
  • /itunes - See /music
  • /list - this will open up a list of all the chat rooms on the server you are currently connected to.
  • /msg user - This will open a private message with the user specified.
  • /music [next, previous, stop, play] - Without any arguments, this will output the song that you are currently listening to, to the chat room you are in.
    • With one of the optional arguments, you can control your music from within Colloquy.
  • /join #room - This will join you to the room specified.
  • /url - See /browser.
  • /query - See /msg.
  • /search search - This will search on http://searchirc.com for a chat room that matches your string
  • /tweet message to tweet - This will post a message to Twitter for you! Note: You have to enter your Twitter username and password in the settings for this to work.
  • /whois username - This will display information about the specified user if they are connected to the same network that you are on.
  • /wikipedia [locale] search - Same as /google, only for wikipedia.
